African-Americans of Omaha, Nebraska, Death Register, 1873-1940. compiled by Jackie Whitaker whitjbar@cox.net This reference book will aid African-Americans in researching their ancestors. It lists the decedents' state of birth and next of kin, marital status, cause of death, and occupation. The cost is $15.00 plus $2.20 postage. [This book notice is for genealogy information only.]

October 1918 DEATH NOTICES

transcribed by Jeanne Rytych

MASONIC FUNURAL – NEBRASKA LODGE NO 1, A.F. & A.M. The funeral services of our late brother, Robert D.R. Weigel, will be held at 2 p.m. Thursday, October 17, at Cole McKay’s chapel, Twenty-sixth and Farnam streets. Masonic service at Forest Lawn Cemetery. Open air service. Master Masons will assemble at Masonic Temple at 1:30 p.m. CHARLES H MARLEY, Worshipful Master. FRANK WILCOX, Secretary. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)CHRISTENSEN – Ida B, died at local hospital Oct 15, 1918 age 42 years. Mrs. George F. Christensen is survived by her husband, George F. Christensen; two sons, Charles and Vernon; four daughters, Florence, Frances, Vera, and Edith Christensen, all of Omaha; one sister, Mrs. E.R. Benson of Portland, Oregon. Private funeral from Crosby chapel, Wednesday, Oct. 16, 1918 at 10: 30 a.m. Interment: Springwell cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)MILLER – Louise, a daughter of Charles E. A. Johnson, superintendent Union depot postal station, died Monday, October 14, at Fremont, Neb. Funeral services will be held at Hulse & Reysen chapel, 701 South Sixteenth street, Thursday morning at 10 o’clock. Interment: Forest Lawn cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)MAGUINESS – Clarence B., aged 30 years, at his residence 2772 California Street. He is survived by his father and mother and sister, Jessie, of the home; two brothers, Jno. P. of Denver and Frank of Co. Bluffs, and a sister, Mrs. Jas. B. McDonald of Maurice, Ia. Funeral notice later. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)BOOTH – Minnie D., October 14, 1918, at Savannah, Mo., of heart failure, aged 39 years. Funeral from Brailey & Dorrance chapel, Nineteenth and Cuming streets, Thursday October 16 [sic], at 2 o’clock. Eastern Star open air service will be held at Mt. Hope cemetery at 2:30 p.m. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)WARREN – Mrs Josephine, age 46 years. Funeral Thursday morning, October 17, at 10 o’clock from Heafey & Heafey chapel, Twenty-sixth and Farnam. Burial Holy Sepulcher cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)SCHROEDER – Herman, age 40 years, St. Joseph hospital. Remains at Heafey & Heafey undertaking parlors, awaiting the arrival of relatives. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)BOCH – Joseph, age 24 years. The remains will be shipped from the Heafey & Heafey chapel, Thursday, October 17, at 4 p.m. to Grand Island, Neb., where services and burial will take place. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)COULTON – Miss Margaret, aged 24 years. Survived by her mother; three brothers, John, David and James. In service of hospital corps and balloon school. Burial will take place Friday at her former home, Marshalltown, Ia. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)KREGIN – Charles, aged 35 years. Survived by his wife, mother, and two brothers. Funeral from John A. Gentleman’s mortuary, Thursday afternoon, 2 p.m. Interment: Holy Sepulcher cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)

COWMAN – Merrell, at Camp Grant, October 14, 1918, aged 25 years. Funeral, Thursday, October 17, at 10 o’clock from Brailey & Dorrance chapel. Services at Forest Lawn cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Nebraska; 17 Oct 1918, Thurs.; Page 11)

transcribed by Jeanne RytychBOLEN – Ivan C. jr., age 1 year 10 months, June 1, at Indianapolis, Ind. Survived by parents, Mr. and Mrs. I. C. Bolen, Sr.; 2 sisters, Shirley and Marylan. Indianapolis, Ind. Funeral services Saturday afternoon at 2 o’clock from the N.P. Swanson Chapel, 17th and Cuming St.. Interment: Flower Hill cemetery, Bennington, Neb. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Neb; 5 Jun 1937; Saturday)GRINNELL – Jeremiah A: Age 79?years. Funeral: Saturday, 2 p.m. Brewer-Korisko Chapel, 24th and K St. Rev. Bryant Howe officiating. Interment: Graceland Park Cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Neb; 5 Jun 1937; Saturday)HALD – Roy, 1906 Chicago age 38 years. Survived by wife, Elsie; 5 daughters, Lucille, Virginia, Lois, Marilyn, Elaine, 2 sons, Earl and Jackie, parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chris Hald, 7 brothers, Clarence, Clayton, Lester, Vernon, Harvey, and Sylvester, all of Omaha, Alfred of San Diego, Cal. Funeral services: Monday at the Hoffmann Mortuary chapel, 2 p.m. Interment: Hillcrest. (Personal Note for LeRoy Hald: Was killed 3 Jun 1937 when a tire he was inflating exploded; died of a skull fracture; worked for the City Street Department, WPA laborer) (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Neb; 5 Jun 1937; Saturday)HANSEN – Mads? A., age 69 years. Funeral: Saturday, 2 p.m. from Heafey & Heafey Farnam St. Home. Interment: Forest Lawn Cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Neb; 5 Jun 1937; Saturday)LANG – Charles B., age 58? years Funeral: Saturday, 3:30 p.m. Brewer-Korisko Chapel, 24th and K St., Rev. W. H. Dickenson officiating. Interment: Graceland Park Cemetery. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Neb; 5 Jun 1937; Saturday)PAYNE – George H., age 73 years, died June. 2. Mr. Payne is survived by his wife; brothers, Henry of Omaha; Fred E. of Anaheim, Cal., Walter of Chippewa, Wis. Funeral services will be held Saturday at 2 o’clock at First Central Congregational church. Interment: Forest Lawn cemetery, will be private. Inquiries may be addressed to the Burket Chapel, HA 0900. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Neb; 5 Jun 1937; Saturday)RAPP – Louise B. 5102 Jackson St., Entered into rest at a local hospital Thursday evening at the age of 49 years. She is survived by her husband Dr. Frank W. Rapp; and brother, Charles Mackeven of Council Bluffs, Ia., and a sister, Emma Reinke of Belon?, Wis. Funeral services: Saturday 2 p.m. at the Huise & Riepen home for funerals. Interment: Walnut Hill cemetery. Council Bluffs, Ia. (“Omaha World Herald”; Omaha, Neb; 5 Jun 1937; Saturday)ROEDEFER – Mrs. Helen, June 3, 1937, age 65 years. Survived by her husband, Frank B., Omaha; 2 brothers, M. L. and Herman Reuter, Chicago, Ill. William J. Turner (age 73, d. Apr. 1921)

MAN WHO SERVED WITH CUSTER DEAD IN SOUTH

Major William J. Turner, United States army, retired, stationed for many years with the old Second Infantry at Fort Omaha and who served in the Indian wars, died this week at St. Petersburg, Fla. He was ill four months and was 73 years old. He is survived by two daughters, Mrs. John G. Workhizer, wife of the former commandant of cadets at the University of Nebraska; Miss Louise E. Turner, and one son, Captain F.E.S. Turner.

The funeral will be at St. Petersburg [Florida] and the body will be taken to Arlington national cemetery for burial.

Major Turner was associated with Buffalo Bill in Indian fighting. He served in the Spanish War.

Source: The World-Herald, Omaha, Saturday Apr 30, 1921

1925 Obituaries

Mary Ann Gugin Johnson Murley (d. Sep 19, 1925) Friends of Mrs. William Murley were sorry to hear of her death on Sunday [Sep 19] afternoon.Funeral services were held at Elk City on Tuesday [Sep 22] at 2 o'clock.Rev. Williams came home from conference to officiate at the services. Note: She was Mary Ann Gugin Johnson Murley.Daughter of James Gugin. Married first Levi Johnson. Buried Elk City NE Cemetery. Virginia (gugin@oregontrail.net) Source: Pilot [Blair, Nebraska], 23 Sep 1925 [Wednesday]
